documents.document: @neva9257 Yup! Like all virtues (though it's not one), if it's not directed to the good, it's merely a 'glittering vice'.

Tread carefully through this selfie-ridden age, friends.
Yesterday I got new glasses and send a picture of them to my family. I didn't explain the reason for the selfie. All they saw was my vanity.

@BubbaMacLeod @SusanCarland That's a different point and one I don't agree with. It's also not supported by (or related to) the article.
@BubbaMacLeod @SusanCarland But each of those is presumably an instance of targetted, malicious killing and basically morally equivalent. 4/
@BubbaMacLeod @SusanCarland Nor does it explain fear or terrorism vs fear of gun death. It would explain car accidents, disease etc... 3/
@BubbaMacLeod @SusanCarland But seeing them as more significant doesn't explain why we exaggerate the likelihood of their occurrence. 2/
@BubbaMacLeod @SusanCarland I think this is part of it. Certain kinds of death and horror are morally worse. We avoid them more strongly. 1/
How biases control us - The psychology of why 94 deaths from terrorism are scarier than 301,797 deaths from guns https://t.co/OGQanJ2X9H
@queenofthinair Thanks!
@queenofthinair who would you recommend reading on the ethics of whistleblowing?
@zaranosaur And so conflates innocent bystander responsibility with the responsibility to restore an injustice one is responsible for?
@zaranosaur I think I follow: Singer's TE paints all passers-by as bystanders rather than as (potentially) having prior responsibility?
@zaranosaur And I'm genuinely asking to learn. I studied ethics but its intersection with political philosophy is somewhat new to me.
@zaranosaur But maybe I'm missing something. What do you see as the apolitical problem?
@zaranosaur I think for a general audience, it's a useful demonstration of why inaction is no more ethically neutral than positive action.
@zaranosaur Yeah I'm not a fan on a number of fronts but the thought experiment is useful for Aus politics atm. https://t.co/jXWgcqvGK3
Singer's drowning child thought experiment teaches us the ethics of inaction. "No comment" is a choice not to critique the status quo.
@wendy_harmer For me the organ donation question is a big one too - although chimeras might provide new organs, there are other options.

@mike_salter Unless you gave the right of objection to everyone, but that may amount to a denial of substantive rights in some cases...
@mike_salter I see. I wonder if there's grey area on that basis though - musicians, professional MC's, etc...
@mike_salter But I'm wondering why you see bakers and florists differently then?
@mike_salter Yeah, exactly. I can see how it might be seen as trying to facilitate cultural change somehow, but it'll be ineffective imo.
@mike_salter In which case you'd eventually weed out the reluctant ones. That has it's own set of ethical issues though.
@mike_salter Maybe the idea is more that if anti-discrimination law applies to celebrants, objectors won't practice anymore...
